welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt: “Think about the different parts of a video game—characters, platforms, UI. If you had to build one of these, what building blocks might you need?” Students discuss in pairs, then share a few answers.

aim.data: Today we’ll learn about how Godot organizes game content using nodes and scenes, and we’ll explore the main interface of the Godot 4 editor.

review.data: Quick recap of Lesson 1.1: opening a project, project manager, basic Godot terminology. Ask: “What did we learn about how a game project is structured in Godot?”

relevant.data:
Mini-Lecture with Live Demo:
- Node: The fundamental building block in Godot. Every element in your game is a node.
- Scene: A scene is a collection (tree) of nodes. Scenes can be saved and reused, even nested.
- Types of Nodes: Node2D, Sprite2D, Label, Button
- Godot Interface Overview: Scene dock, Viewport, FileSystem, Inspector, Toolbar, Script Editor

interactive.data:
Student Activity – Build Your First Scene:
- Open a Godot project.
- Add a new scene with a Node2D root named Main.
- Add a Sprite2D and load a built-in image.
- Add a Label that says “Hello, Godot!”
- Save the scene as main.tscn and play the scene.
- Share: What did you change in the Inspector? How did it affect the scene?

ownership.data:
Independent Practice:
- Add a Button to your scene.
- Change the text and modify the font size and anchor position in the Inspector.
- Bonus Challenge: Try attaching a script and explore signals (to be explained in detail later).

resonate.data: Exit Ticket Prompt: “How do nodes and scenes make it easier to build games in Godot?” Students write responses on paper or digitally.

supplies.data: Computers with Godot 4 installed, Projector/instructor demo system, Internet access (optional), Template Godot project, Access to sprite image files or built-in resources.
